content: The "Advance Directive Promotion Act of 2008" includes sections on improving policies related to advance directives, Medicare coverage for end-of-life planning consultations, a national information hotline for end-of-life decision-making, and increasing awareness of end-of-life planning. The "Advance Directive Promotion Act of 2008" amends Medicare regulations to include the content of advance directives in medical records, provide individuals with the opportunity to discuss related issues with a professional, and improve end-of-life planning consultations. The "Advance Directive Promotion Act of 2008" amends Medicare regulations to include the content of advance directives in medical records and allows providers to honor out-of-state advance directives to the same extent as in-state directives, preempting any inconsistent state laws. The "Advance Directive Promotion Act of 2008" amends Medicaid regulations to include advance directive content in medical records. The "Advance Directive Promotion Act of 2008" amends Medicaid regulations to include advance directive content in medical records. It requires providers to offer individuals the opportunity to discuss information provided and to honor out-of-state advance directives to the same extent as in-state directives. The "Advance Directive Promotion Act of 2008" allows for out-of-state advance directives to be valid, preempting any inconsistent state laws. The amendments apply to provider agreements under title XVIII of the Social Security Act and State plans under title XIX, with an effective date specified by the Secretary of Health and Human Services within one year of enactment. The effective date for State plans under title XIX of the Social Security Act may be extended if State legislation is required to meet additional requirements imposed by amendments. The State plan will not be considered non-compliant solely for failing to meet these requirements before the first day of the first calendar quarter after the State legislature's regular session following the Act's enactment. MEDICARE COVERAGE OF AN END-OF-LIFE PLANNING CONSULTATION AS PART OF AN INITIAL PREVENTIVE PHYSICAL EXAMINATION. Medicare coverage includes an end-of-life planning consultation, which involves discussions on advance directives, reliance on them, benefits of a comprehensive end-of-life plan, and identifying resources for treatment wishes based on state requirements. The amendments made by this section apply to initial preventive physical examinations furnished on or after January 1, 2009. SEC. 4. NATIONAL INFORMATION HOTLINE FOR END-OF-LIFE DECISIONMAKING AND HOSPICE CARE. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will establish a 24-hour toll-free hotline to provide information on advance directives, end-of-life decisionmaking, and hospice care services. SEC. 5. INCREASING AWARENESS OF THE IMPORTANCE OF END-OF-LIFE PLANNING. Title III of the Public Health Service Act will be amended to emphasize the importance of end-of-life planning. Title III of the Public Health Service Act is amended to include a new part focused on programs to increase awareness of advance directive planning issues, specifically through advance directive education campaigns. The Secretary will conduct a national public education campaign to raise awareness about planning for care near the end of life, understanding advance directives, the importance of legal documents expressing health care wishes, and the availability of hospice and palliative care. At least 60 percent of funds will be used for grants to public or nonprofit entities for this purpose. The text chunk discusses the purpose of awarding grants to public or nonprofit entities for conducting education campaigns for a period of 3 years. $25,000,000 is authorized for appropriations for this purpose.
